Patch Set 9: Ok-To-Test+1

User approved, CI ok to start
A number of mostly pretty minor things...looks alright overall though.
Is there any particular reason to have these as macros?  Seems like we might as well stick with the existing style of `constexpr size_t` instead.
This function name seems a little awkward to me ; I'd suggest `parseMultirecordUUID()` instead.

Looks like the declaration in the header didn't get updated to match -- however, since the function is only used within fru_utils.cpp (hence it presumably still compiling with the mismatch, though a CI run to confirm would be good...), it would probably be better to make it a static function in fru_utils.cpp and remove it from the header entirely if it's an internal-use-only function.
Given that the other names of the elements in this enum are written out in full, seems like we might as well expand "Sup" to "Supply" and "Out" to "Output" here.

Nit: I think it'd be slightly clearer to use `resv` as an abbreviated prefix for "reserved" instead of just `res` (which by appearance I'd be more likely to interpret as meaning "resource" or something).  Also, I'd suggest putting "ASF" part in all-caps.
Formatting here looks a bit off (perhaps that why CI complained, though at this point unfortunately the jenkins link is a 404).

Is there a symbolic name we could use for this magic index?  (Or if not, should we create one?)  If I'm reading things right though, I think 5 would be the value returned by the getHeaderAreaFieldOffset() call above, so maybe just `if (areaOffset != 0)` instead...?
Is there a particular reason to cast both operands to int instead of just casting managementAccessRecord to uint8_t?

Likewise here.

Also, should we check recordLength as well?  (i.e. just to check for corrupt/malformed FRU data.)
I'm guessing the hard-coded 6 here is essentially multiRecordHeaderLen plus one to skip past the sub-record type byte?  Assuming so, it would be good to make that a little clearer.
What purpose does the uuidBin variable serve here?  It looks like it could be removed and you could just use the uuidReorder buffer directly instead.

Hi Zev,

Thanks for your review. I have updated it. Please help review.
Still some minor formatting issues; you'll need to get approved for CI to get coverage on this (which will also run clang-format to point out all the necessary formatting changes to make).
As suggested above, looks like this could be static (and moved before formatIPMIFRU() in the file to avoid the need for a separate declaration).
Thank you for your review. I have updated it. Please help review.

Looks okay to me aside from the one minor thing noted below, though Ed or Zhikui will need to approve as well.

However, I notice that (contrary to what I'd thought) it looks like CI isn't actually running clang-format...I'll try to look into why that's not happening .

Hi Zev, I have updated it.
Thanks

After some discussion on discord, the CI/clang-format thing is a semi-known problem; hopefully it'll get fixed before too long, but in the meantime you can try running clang-format-15 locally (with the .clang-format config file in the repo).  In case you're not set up to do that easily, here are the changes I got from running it myself: https://gist.github.com/zevweiss/6818b351a6d850ad0b72b25e89a36c1e

> One other little tidy-up while taking care of the formatting issues -- the formatting directives (hex, setfill, setw) don't need to be re-applied on every iteration, so this would be cleaner as just:
> 
> ```
> tmp << hex << setfill('0') << setw(2);
> for (...)
> {
>   tmp << uuidReorder[i];
> }
> ```
> 
> (Also, I'd suggest simplifying `sizeof(uint8_t) * 2` to just `2`.)

Hi Zev,

I changed it as per your suggestion, but have an issue. The UUID is shown as:
e74d8ad8-ed3b-11ec-ace5-de1705a234
instead of e74d8ad8-ed3b-11ec-ace5-de01705a0234.
Missing the 0 in the 11th byte(01)
Missing the 0 in the 14th byte(02).
So, I still keep the old implementation. Just update the `sizeof(uint8_t) * 2` to just `2`.

Please help review.

Hi Zev,

I have updated it. Please help review.
verify checksum of the area/record is missing

Hi Zhikui, Zev

Thank you for your review. I have update it. Please help review.

Hi Zev Weiss, Zhikui Ren
Friendly ping.
we can use const std::vector<uint8_t>& device
to avoid out-of-boundary scenario, we can use device.at(getHeaderAreaFieldOffset)
nit: we can move this above line no 297

To test all access (like line344) within the loop is not going to be out of bound of device:
areaOffset + uuidRecordData + uuidDataLen < device.size()

[] operator doent do boundary check , consider using .at()

other places too
at() can throw exception and is also slower. Boundary checking and [] should be used. Other places also
accessing 2 arrays , we need some size check here to perevent ou-of-boundary issue
nit: directly use device[areaOffset + 2] instead of using extra variable

Hi Zhikui, gokulsvg
I updated it. Please help review.
